Ben:

FWIW, I use {href:"...", rel:"..."} sufficient decoration for most al=
l
cases (i.e. no "type" decoration). my clients are "coded to the rel"
and =
that's all.

Also, I am usually wary of people who say things like "we coul=
d just
figure that out implicitly" as this often introducing "coupling base=
d
on assumption" that can limit future mods/enhancements down the line.

Fi=
nally, I don't use a "type" decoration since this leads my client
apps into=
 expecting strongly-typed "objects" in the response
representation. I try t=
o avoid this expectation. What clients get back
is a representation in the =
agree media type. Clients are then able to
process the representation using=
 the media type rules and compute,
render, and when appropriate, activate t=
he hypermedia in the response.
The "type" is not needed for those steps.

n your case, what is it that the "type" value is used for by the client app=
s?

> I've defined a read only API where l=
inks to other resources follow an Atom like model and include the media-typ=
e & relation as well as the URI, so they look something like this in JSON:
=
>
> links: [ { href: "/foo", type: "fooType", rel: "self" },
> =A0 =A0 =A0 =
=A0 { href: "/bar", type: "barType", rel: "http://example.com/customeRel" ]=

>
> In a conversation with someone who is not entirely into the whole REST=
 thing they commented
>
> "including the type & relation in the link is ext=
ra complexity, if we did it in XML we could just figure that out implicitly=
 from the schema when we GET the linked resource"
>
> Leaving aside XML Vs =
JSON arguments (which aren't relevant to my question) I justified it with a=
n argument that explicitly including the relation meant you didn't need to =
GET the resource to know what the relationship was (as the same type could =
have different relations to different resources, e.g. parent vs child relat=
ions) and including the type meant the client could know what it was going =
to GET without actually getting it - e.g. "I don't need to know about barTy=
pes right now so I won't bother getting them until I need to know about the=
m"
>
> But afterwards I thought to myself while my arguments above seem rea=
sonable there must be other good reasons (that I can't immediately think of=
) for being explicit with types & relations in links in RESTful APIs.
